Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: How will marine ecosystems respond to climate change? Integrating K-12 teaching and paleoceanographic research
Award.AbstractNarration:
Fundamental shifts in the Earth's ocean ecosystems and carbon cycle are currently underway due to anthropogenic processes, and the implications of these shifts are still poorly understood. Paleoceanographic records provide a unique opportunity to understand how ecosystems have responded to rapid climate change in the past. This work, led by a faculty member at the University of California at Davis, will utilize exquisite sediment records from Santa Barbara Basin (SBB) to reconstruct how seafloor biodiversity responded to changes in temperature and oxygenation during past time periods of rapid warming. This project builds upon the recent discovery that a wide variety of invertebrate taxonomic groups, including arthropods, molluscs, and echinoderms, are abundantly preserved in SBB sediments, and thus can be directly compared to more established records of climate change. The investigations of sedimentary communities will focus on three areas:

1) modern fauna, using recently collected box cores that span 300-1200m on the California margin,
2) a depth transect of cores from SBB spanning the deglaciation, the most abrupt climate change in recent geologic history, and
3) Mid-Pleistocene sediment records that have provided evidence of pervasive millennial-scale climate change throughout the past 1 Ma.

A key to understanding the complexities of climate change impacts on ocean environments is the synthesis of biological, geological, chemical and physical information. This research will directly tackle that integration, and be combined with an effort to educate future math and science teachers and K-12 students by collaborating with the successful UC Davis Math and Science Teaching (MAST) program. Each year, MAST students will develop, test, and modify climate science curriculum during the fall, which will then be utilized for visiting classrooms the following spring. Summer Fellowships will provide full financial support for MAST students (2/year) to take summer intensive field courses at Bodega Marine Laboratory (BML) and complete independent research projects. At the completion of their MAST Fellowship, students will utilize their independent research projects and data as inspiration for the next round of MAST-student led curriculum development.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Paleoceanographic records provide unique opportunities to understand how marine systems have responded to rapid climate change in the past, and make predictions for the future. This project aimed to use sediment records from California to reconstruct how marine ecosystems respond to changes in temperature and oxygenation during time periods of rapid warming over the past 20,000 years. In particular, we used microfossils -very small, and yet well preserved shells from marine organisms that are present in marine sediments – to reconstruct environmental change through time. As part of this research, the thesis research for four Ph.D. students was directly supported; a suite of other graduate students benefitted from mentoring, resources, and opportunities provided by this program. One postdoctoral scholar was significantly supported by this program, who provided guidance and collaboration on our education and outreach goals. A total of 13 undergraduates were supported in mentored research projects and laboratory experience as part of this work, from UC Davis, Carleton College, and Santa Rosa Junior College. This research generated scientific findings that were published in seven peer-reviewed publications, as well as being featured on student blogs, university press releases, and media.

 

In our research, we found that microfossils, including single-celled organisms (foraminifera) as well as well-preserved gastropods, bivalves, and urchin remains can be used as sensitive records of environmental change. In particular, we document the expansion of low oxygen waters over thousands of years, as well as more recent changes in the past 500 years, that have altered marine ecosystems. We find that while disturbance from the presence of low oxygen waters can nearly instantaneously alter the species present, it can take decades or even centuries for ecosystems to recover from such disturbance. We also document impacts on living species that are in the ocean today – and how continued changes in the ocean environment will pose challenges for these small organisms at the bottom of the food web.

 

As part of this work, we collaborated with the UC Davis CalTeach Math & Science Teaching (MAST) program to help pre-service teachers develop curriculum for their classrooms. Over the course of the project, over a dozen curriculum ideas were generated and tested; five of these were incorporated into use by area teachers and have been made public for other teachers to use. This curriculum developed by early career educators covers topics such as Arctic ice, marine plastic pollution, ocean acidification, and healthy estuaries. UC Davis students involved in this program have gone on to pursue careers in K-12 education, as well as medical school and other graduate programs.

 

As a component of our outreach and education activities, we hosted a workshop focused on building a community of paleoclimate researchers who will collaborate with managers and policymakers. The workshop included 30 experts in paleoclimate science, policy, conservation, and science communication. This community of researchers continues to work together to try to improve the use of paleoclimate data in critical decision making on climate and environmental change.

 

The support from this award was invaluable, and transformative, to PI Hill and everyone in this lab, during an important time in our research program. The CAREER award provided critical stability and opportunities for novel research that would not have been possible otherwise.
